snippet.textDisplay: I was raised a witness and I totally get what you are trying to say and trying not to say. Having family members still in that organization is... a difficult situation. Their attitude towards ex-members is particularly hurtful. And your experience in the organization that you describe above is... I could have written that about myself; especially the part about the fear. I believe this is so hard and hurtful to you because it's not just about your Dad and your wedding. It's wrapped up in your entire experience with the witnesses and how that childhood has hurt you. This situation probably pokes at that old wound and make it all so much bigger; those old wounds feel fresh again. But good for you talking about it. Exposing all of this to the light is the best thing for it. You made it through the first time. You will make it though this.

snippet.textDisplay:
I wouldn't feel bad about losing family over this. You really are better off without that crap in your life, and I'm not singling out the JWs. I mean all of that religious nonsense. Drop it like a hot rock, you'll be better off without the pointless baggage.

Remember, like another commenter said, the "blood is thicker than water" quote actually reads:
"The blood of the covenant is thicker than the water of the womb." It means simply that the family you make (friends, lovers, children, and the like) are FAR more important those simply related by blood.

snippet.textDisplay: My wife and I went through the same thing with her mother. My wife mother has never really accepted that her daughter is gay nor has she really accepted me. My wife's mother texted my wife the NIGHT before our wedding and told her daughter that she would not be able to make it because it was against her beliefs. We have since tried to have a relationship with her and try to meet her half way, but she never really meets us half way. We have now been married for 5 years this year (YAY) and my mother in law has never seen our house that we bought together. My wife and i are now expecting a baby!!! My mother in law was not to thrilled about finding out she was going to be a grandmother, she did not attend our gender reveal and she did not attend our baby shower. My wife has come to terms with that her mother will more than likely not be in our child's life. My wife knows that she has so may other people in her family that are there for us but i know that it still does hurt, she just doesn't talk about it. I think more people should openly talk about their situations like this so that other know, you are not alone. So thank you for sharing your experience! And you are not alone in this!!!! We can't wait to see all of your wedding content!!!!!!

snippet.textDisplay:
If it may lighten your load, I have been raised as a Jehovah's Witness. Also, as an Asian-American, the difficulty of living under immigrant parents made it worse.

I did not know the reality of this world and thought the witnesses teachings were all true. But college opened my eyes and the world shattering realization have been too hard to bear. Fast forward 7 years, I decided to make as much money as I could, something that they do not encourage. I am on an agenda to attack this organization that took my family, my youth, and my future. Let go of your pain. You found someone that matters to you most and who you can pour your attention to. Getting your family back or attacking the organization is a very lonely and dark path and won't advise anyone to do the same. Cheer up and hang in there Hannah.

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you for being so vulnerable.  Your pain is familiar,  albeit caused by a different religion/organization, and for me, it hurts so much because these people cause pain, over and over again; not with malicious intent, and not by accident, but with a purpose they consider righteous, and dare I say, because they care.  They hurt too, because the thing they hold higher than anything else, their religion, has convinced them that us non-believers, will be annihilated, or are going to hell, etc.  I can only imagine being a parent, convinced my child is headed towards the worst fate imaginable. Of course they would try to "save us".  Explain the "wrongness of our ways".  The whole situation is a fucked up, vicious cycle.  Best we can do is not let it taint the pureness of our happiness. Hugs to you and Ella.

Saying „I‘m so so sorry you have to go through this“ sounds somehow hollow even so I deeply mean it. ❤️❤️❤️ Nobody who hasn‘t experienced something like this can‘t probably fully understand but we all know that a parent should love their child unconditionally. So when they don‘t, it fucks you up in a way and healing from that must be hard.
You deserve more, so so much more and to see you hurting like this is heartbreaking.
Just remember that your chosen family loves you SO much and will always be there for you. You are lovely and kind and loving and funny and a wonderful person. They can‘t and won‘t take that from you, ever! I wish you and Ella a truly amazing life together!!!

snippet.textDisplay:
Hannah, I am married to an ex-JW. My husband's dad is super-devout, as pretty much all "good" witnesses are. Years ago my husband's father called him on the phone to tell him that since my husband wasn't a "good" witness anymore, that he was no longer his son and that his dad wouldn't be acknowledging him. My father-in-law then has gone out of his way to make sure that my husband's grown son has been essentially forced to shun him too. I haven't seen my stepson or my stepson's new wife (they're 21) in going on three years, and it's not like we lived far away. My husband saw his son late last year because we have relocated states, and so his son took 40 minutes out of his day to have lunch with him during his first drive from old-state to new-state. We keep asking them to come visit, which leads to unanswered texts or unanswered phone calls. It's been a big adjustment. But everything you said here ... hits home with us over here.

Please know that when the org takes them away from us it's just that, it's the org. It's not them deciding, it's the org deciding. And all we can do is be who we are and be here if they ever decide to break away from the org.

You aren't alone and the rest of this crazy world is going to fill your wedding day and your married life with love and joy.

snippet.textDisplay:
My father isn’t religious, but he also doesn’t choose me or my little brother. He chooses himself and no one else. It’s hard. Knowing he’s out there, not even caring about us at all. Popping into our lives when it’s convenient for him or when he wants something. It has messed us both up more than I can say and more than I can ever understand.. our mother chose drugs and other men and we never met her. As children she filled our heads with empty promises, then nothing at all.

Having a parent who doesn’t choose you and doesn’t try.. it’s devastating and it damages you even when you don’t know it. It took me a long time to realize just how deep it goes and I still haven’t reached the full extent.
If you can, I really encourage you to seek professional therapy or counselling. Talking helps.

snippet.textDisplay:
Oh Hanna,
First I’m sorry that you are so sad. If I may say you will find that as the years go by you will find that having a relationship with your unresponsive father will no longer matter in any way whatsoever. In my family there is no religious excuse or really any excuse for the utter lack of interest in my life. “It just is” I quit asking why a long time ago and found a place of acceptance. I focus on the absolutely fabulous people who are in my life and appreciate the great life I have made for myself despite the people who called themselves my parents. In fact, I could not / would not have my current amazing life if I had held onto my parents judgement and perspective. I knew I could only change my own perspective.
Congratulations and best wishes. You found someone absolutely lovely to build your life forward. Already you have taken the first big step towards your best life and acceptance. Ultimately it is your dad who is missing out but that is his decision. I promise you it won’t matter an iota as your life and partnership with your wife and relationships with good people and close friends grow.

snippet.textDisplay: I am so so sorry you are dealing with this. I got married a few months ago and my husbands mom, dad and two siblings didn’t come to our wedding. We are not religious so we had a non religious ceremony. His family refused to attend because we didn’t have the wedding at their also cult like church. It really hurt us both and has put a huge damper on our relationship with them. We knew that they wouldn’t come to the wedding before he proposed but it still hurts when it actually happens despite being expected. We still had an amazing wedding. No attention was brought to the fact that his family wasn’t there. We made the decision that this is something his family will have to live with and regret. They are the ones who should be feeling upset, not us. As hard as it was to “sweep under the rug”, we decided our happiness and marriage were more important than spending the time planning the wedding stressing about them. As awful as it is, you will look back on your wedding day remembering the beautiful day with your beautiful wife. He will look back and remember the decision he chose not to be there. This is his burden, not yours.

snippet.textDisplay: My brother didn’t come to my wedding because I’m a lesbian. It’s nowhere near not having a parent there, but I get being rejected for who you are. I saw him at my mothers funeral 4 months later and he was so rude to my wife that I decided then and there to cut the cancer out of my life. It still hurts. We were very close growing up until I came out. I’ve learned a lot out of that situation. I learned that sometimes family isn’t blood and also that I have way more blood family that love me and support me. I realized that I don’t need his approval to be happy. But it still hurts everyday. I’ve mourned him as though he died because I don’t know what else to do. But I’m happy and I have the most amazing marriage. He is alone and a miserable human. I think I won that battle.

snippet.textDisplay: This may be shocking but I'm actually a gay man and I completely understand why her father is refusing to come to her wedding. We as gay people cannot expect other people to Simply put aside their lifelong beliefs just because we think they're wrong. I know it's crazy to think this way but I think we should respect their beliefs as much as we want them to accept and respect our beliefs

snippet.textDisplay: I remember when I was a little girl before I fully cut my birth mother out of my life, back when I wanted to be the "good baptist daughter" she wanted, I asked her "What would you think if I brought a girlfriend home instead" while we talked about boyfriends and wedding stuff. She told me in so many words "You'll go to hell for that because it's a sin". She had abused me and emotionally manipulated me and my Dad for years (my Dad far worse and much longer, 18 years total, 12 of which before my birth) so I shouldn't have been so surprised by that but yeah it hurt me more than I thought it would and it was one of the first things to put a crack in that "perfect daughter" facade which would later allow me to finally be fed up with her bullshit and end her control over me once and for all. I don't know if that last part is true since although I'd like to think I could stand up to her if she ever started one of her tirades at me again, part of me worries I'd crawl back inside myself like the scared five-year-old hiding behind the couch waiting for the yelling to stop. I still flinch just thinking about that, thinking about ... her.

snippet.textDisplay:
I’m so so happy that your mum chose to take you and your sister away from that environment. You come from a line of incredibly strong women, don’t forget that.

My dad has never really been around - no religion or anything took him away from me. He just never really tried. I’m in the U.K. and he lives in Sweden (1hr and a half flight for under £100) and when I nearly died at 19 years old of an undiagnosed heart condition, he didn’t jump on the plane. I’m fortunate enough to have grown up with incredible males in my life so I don’t feel like I’m missing out - but I don’t know how I’ll feel about it all if/when I get married.

You care because it’s instinctual - don’t beat yourself up about it. You’re the bigger person in every way and I hope that someday he wakes up and sees what he’s been missing all these years.
Have an incredible wedding and life, you’ve worked so hard and overcome so much. You deserve to have the best time ❤️

snippet.textDisplay: I grew up as a witness and even though we live in a time where people are very liberal thinkers the witnesses "believe" they are true Christians and would never support homosexuality or lesbianism. Unfortunately it is scriptural, 1 Corinthians 6:9-11. Even with that being said, my Mom and Dad did not come to my wedding because I didnt marry another witness. So this unloving provision of "shunning" family and friends is normal for them. Its what the organization teaches and millions of other young people have experienced this same treatment. Time will heal but you'll never forget and the stinch of hurt will linger, you just have to keep going and keep pushing thru this. Im so sorry you are going thru this crazy experience with your Dad. Continue to be around those who Love you for you. You are right, they are a cult. They are even considered the anti christ based on some of their teachings. I'm no longer a witness and I dont believe what they teach. At this point you have to surround yourself with family and friends who love you unconditionally. I did and Im ok. You will be ok too, with time. Good luck with everything.

snippet.textDisplay: It's not fine, as a parent you choose your kids over everything, anything else is just stuff.. if your kid is gay, straight, or somewhere in the middle, it doesn't matter.. they are still your children. You support them for what they are because a little part of you is carried on in them. You make sure they are healthy, protected, educated, and have self worth, you make sure they know they always have someone they can turn to, and always have a home, no matter what happens.. it's despicable to me that someone would hurt such a kind soul.. i wish you a lifetime of happiness.. you deserve far better than what you have been given. snippet.textDisplay: As someone who grew up in that world, I completely understand. I spent my formidable years feeling I'd never be worthy of anything because I knew in my heart I was gay. Had I come out, that one fact would prevent me from ever achieving even the slightest value. It took me years to realize I was worthy of so much. I knew exactly why you choked up on the word apostate. There is little in that world that is worse. For so many of us, the recent documentary opened a cavern of old wounds and hurts. Have an awesome life knowing and believing that it's not you who is missing out because of a choice.  Keep that joy because you are outstandingly awesome.

It's strange to feel close to you though we have never met and likely never will. I was also raised in a cult and do not have the unconditional love of a parent who is still a part of the mormon "organization". It is very much conditional because I know I would be more accepted and loved if I were not atheist and if I were heterosexual and well, if I wasn't me. We are all more than the sum of our parts. But those are two very important parts of my identity that were hard fought for. Watching a loved one continually choose blind faith over you, their child is an incredibly awful feeling. I get not really being surprised by their actions, but more so your reaction to it. Of course that shit still hurts though. Thanks for sharing such intimate parts of you. I'm proud of you, Hannah. snippet.textDisplay:
I'm a woman and my husband and I never formally had a wedding, but family on his side insisted that we have a reception to celebrate us. Only one family member her two really little ones on my side showed up. Even the ones who said they'd be there didn't come. My dad was supposed to be there. I just wanted him there, I didn't mind if his wife and kids didn't come, I just wanted my dad to be there on a day for me for once. I cried til 6 in the morning. He and the others didn't even tell me they wouldn't be there, they told my aunt instead. Some people didn't even tell me one way or the other. This happened in October and I don't think I've ever been more heartbroken and it still affects me.
I'm so sorry your dad chose himself and his cult over you. I wish I could hug you because my dad throughout my whole life, chose himself over me too.

snippet.textDisplay: I am so sorry for your pain. I know I don't know your relationship with your father, but I hope you don't let this revolve around your choosing to be with a woman. It revolves around the seclusion of the JWs, and their encouragement of isolation apart from everyone who is not a JW member. My husband's best friend is a JW, and we wanted him to be one of our few groomsmen. He initially agreed, but after consulting with other JW members, he backed out because he could not support a non-JW wedding, heterosexual or not. His JW parents, who are family friends, did not come to our wedding. I feel lucky that we have any relationship with him, as not everyone in the organization is supportive of being friends with those who are not members, regardless of their sexuality or whatever. Again, I'm so sorry... but remember that the good side of this is that you will not have to worry about judgmental eyes on your wedding day. Bask in those who love you unconditionally.

snippet.textDisplay: This is bullshit, I grew up up a witness and although I myself am not one I do NOT think it is a cult. Just because you may have grown up in a problematic family that associated themselves as witnesses doesn't mean you get to pin that on every other one. Grow the fuck up, religion doesn't have to be a cult because they don't accept everyone. It's just something we have to get used to and as a member of the LGBTQ community I can even see that.

snippet.textDisplay: i also grew up a jehovah’s witness and got disfellowshipped at 15 and left the house at 17. i haven’t spoken to my father since. i haven’t spoken to most of my family since i was 15. i know they’ll never be a part of my life and it hurts a lot. i’ve been struggling with it a lot more recently because i suppressed it for so long and i’m finally dealing with the emotions and heartbreak. my grandfather died after i got excommunicated and i never got to say goodbye to him. i have a weird dynamic regarding the relationship with my mom. i love her so much but i think her love is conditional. she assured me it’s not but i just have been abandoned so much that i can never get that fear out my head. she’s still a jehovah’s witness and married to my father so things can change at any point and it’s so scary. it’s drove me into a depression and has completely changed my life. i was the only person there for myself and had to protect myself at a vulnerable age. i am still in high school and have to navigate all this change on my own. my mom and i talk but we never see each other because my dad doesn’t know we communicate. it’s just so scary and it is a cult. i went through 10 months of conversion therapy under them. the only reason i was allowed out of conversion therapy was because one of their members attempted to sexually assault me and i was released under the condition of my silence to the authorities. i am traumatized by this religion and it still consumes me. i started self harming in 6th grade because of the religion. i attempted suicide. this religion has made me a stronger person but has given me so many issues. i can’t develop deep relationships because i have abandonment issues. everyone i grew up with stopped talking to me overnight. that changes a person. i can’t trust people. i don’t talk about this openly so i’m sharing it in the comments section in hopes that if someone reads this they know they aren’t alone and there’s other people that are going through similar situations. i understand the pain in this video in more ways than i’d care to admit. i’m sorry to anyone who has to go through this.

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you so much for being so fucking vulnerable and honest. I really needed to hear what you shared, even though our experiences are so different. I feel so much less alone. But I’m also so angry and upset for you. As a Mum of a ten year old son, I will always choose him and have always put his needs above selfishness. Our children should always come first. My partner and I have three kids and even though they aren’t all biologically mine, they all are the lights of my life. I’ve learnt from my own experiences as a child on how I have to be a parent. I can’t do things my parents did, so I just want you to know that despite what’s happened to you with your father, it’s going to make you an incredible mama one day if you choose to be. Shitty parents can make us better parents. Sending you such a big hug. Enjoy your wedding, it’ll be magical. Now you get to build YOUR family. I promise it gets better when you do that. 💜

snippet.textDisplay: This really hit home for me, but the other way around for me. My girlfriends dad and stepmom have never met me or even seen me. They've known about me since we've been together, but they said they didn't want to meet me. Her step mom plain out said she never wants to meet me, see me, or hear anything about me. Her dad only tolerates me because he doesn't want to lose his daughter. For me it just hurts me to see how hard it is for her to have to deal with people; who are suppose to love her unconditionally, refuse to open their minds and eyes up just a little to see that after everything she's been through she is finally happy. I don't get how someone can say they love you so much, but not be able to support and accept their child no matter what! Love has nothing to do with convenience to anyone or anything, and love should not be in spite of anything. She loves her father unconditionally; through all the pain that he's put her through, and unknowingly continues to put her through (since she hasn't told him how much it affects her). I wish that she didn't have to go through this or anyone for that matter. It breaks my heart to see a person who is just trying to love another person could be judged by someone who is only meant to protect you from the world. It's so sad to see that the person meant to protect you, is the one who hurts you the most.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm so sorry.. But what you're sharing is powerful! I'm a mom from the deep south who grew up in a fundamentalist religion who started watching your videos because you are a funny Lady that drinks and cooks things. You are reaching a huge audience and by sharing are helping to normalize gay relationships. This brought me to tears! People are seeing your pain and learning how to empathize and understand. I'm sorry you have to live through this - you are an amazing person. I hope you have an amazing wedding day.
